Award.AwardTitle: Excellence in Research: Evaluating thiol-peptides with auxiliary binding groups as chelators of mercury(II)
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, co-funded by the Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate program and the Chemical Structure, Dynamic and Mechanism B program, Professor Maria Ngu-Schwemlein and her collaborator Dr. John Merle, of the Chemistry Department at Winston Salem State University are developing eco-friendly biomolecules to sequester toxic mercury ions. The goal of this project is to design effective thiol-peptides to immobilize mercury ions for applications in environmental remediation of mercury polluted water, and as sensors or reporters of mercury ions. It may also afford a basis for future research in developing genetically engineered plants that are useful for phytoremediation. This project lies at the interface of bioorganic, inorganic, analytical, and computational chemistry, and therefore provides an excellent breadth of education for scientists and students. The project activities also provide a high level of education and research training to prepare undergraduates, primarily underrepresented groups at this historically black university, for entry into advanced degree programs and careers in science.

Peptides offer inherent high affinities for their targets due to the versatility of its monomeric units, which offer a wide variety of donor atoms and contribute to specific secondary structures. The proposed syntheses include thiol-peptides with different auxiliary binding groups to evaluate complex formation with mercury(II) and to assess for enhanced mercury(II) immobilization through increased complex stability. In this project, oligopeptides consisting of di- or multi-cysteinyl residues with added auxiliary groups (O-, N-, or aromatic pi donors) are prepared to answer the following questions: (1) How do multi-thiol peptides containing different auxiliary donors form complexes with mercury(II)? (2) Can auxiliary binding groups form significant binding specificities resulting in sterically hindered peptide-mercury complexes that are kinetically stable? (3) What is the significance and stability of type II beta turn in cysteinyl peptides for binding mercury(II)? (4) What are the spatial accessibilities in these peptide ligands that can be identified for chemical conjugation with carriers or fluorophores for immobilizing and sensing mercury(II)? The findings from this study could be useful for developing effective chelators of mercury(II) for applications in environmental remediation, human health protection, and sensing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, co-funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic and Mechanism B program and the Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate program, Professor Maria Ngu-Schwemlein and her collaborator Dr. John Merle, of the Chemistry Department at Winston Salem State University developed eco-friendly biomolecules to sequester toxic mercury ions.  The goal of this project is to design effective thiol-peptides to immobilize mercury ions for future applications in environmental remediation of mercury polluted water, and as sensors or reporters of mercury ions.  This project lies at the interface of bioorganic, inorganic, analytical, and computational chemistry, and provided a breadth of education for scientists and students.  The project activities also provided a high level of education and research training to prepare undergraduates, primarily underrepresented groups at this historically black university, for entry into advanced degree programs and careers in science. 

Some project activities that have been implemented to support the above scientific and educational project goals include: (i) design and preparation of various series of small peptide biomolecules (tri-, tetra- penta-, and cyclo-peptides); (ii) spectroscopic, calorimetric, and computational studies of how these peptides interact with mercury ions; (iii) participation of WSSU undergraduates and high school students in research activities; (iv) preparation of underrepresented students for advanced degree programs in chemistry and biosciences; (v) acquisition and upgrade of instrumentation to enhance infrastructure for research and student training; (vi) infusion of research skills into instructional chemistry lab courses; (vii) professional development and collaborations with nearby research universities; and (ix) dissemination of project activities and findings via student presentations at local and national meetings, and publications in peer reviewed research journals.

Some project outcomes include:

  1. Peptides containing CWC motifs and tryptophan indoles have been shown to enhance immobilization of mercury(II). They can be advantageous for the development of better chelators of mercury ions for applications in environmental remediation, human health protection, and sensing.
  2. Three peer reviewed research journal publications (doi:10.1016/j.ica.2020.119552;  doi.org/10.1016/j.bmc.2021.116296; doi.org/10.1155/2021/9911474) on work and research findings from this research project, and a science communication publication (https://doi.org/10.33548/SCIENTIA653).
  3. Six undergraduate students participated in this research project activities and training each year, including local high school students. Six of these students have continued to advanced degree programs in chemistry or biosciences and five are working in local chemical or biochemical industries.
  4. Increased in student research presentations at local, regional, and national meetings. Over ten student presentations resulted from this project activities despite the global pandemic and associated restrictions.
  5. This project also contributed toward one of NSF’s effort in fulfilling its mission by broadening the participation of groups underrepresented in STEM disciplines. 
  6. Increased partnership with nearby research universities (University of North Carolina at Greensboro, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and the Joint School of Nanoengineering and Nanoscience at Greensboro) enhanced the research capacity (access to state-of-the-art research facilities) of the department in preparing undergraduates, primarily underrepresented groups, at this historically black university, for entry into advanced degree programs and careers in science.

This project indirectly also supports other research initiatives at Winston-Salem State University including the WSSU Council for Undergraduate Research (CUR) Transformation project, WSSU NIH NIGMS RISE program, NSF LSAMP program, WSSU research initiatives for undergraduates, an outreach program to a local elementary science club, and a science internship program at a local high school, Simon G. Atkins Academic and Technology High School.
